Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Carbide Bonded Graphene Coating for Enhanced Glass Molding
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is in significantly lowering the cost of high precision glass molding through a low-cost carbide-bonded graphene coating. In optical industry, optical glasses have been the de facto choice. These lenses are used in cameras, projection systems and military equipment. However, cost and other considerations frequently lead to the choice of injection molded plastic lenses with their acceptable but lower image quality. The innovative carbide-bonded graphene coatings are both low cost and durable, and could allow use of precision optical glasses in places where plastic products are used today. The coatings also have the potential to spread to other markets such as advanced thermal management, next generation electronic components, and biosensors based on the unique combination of excellent mechanical, physical, optical transparency and biocompatibility properties together with tunable optoelectronic characteristics. Such products may greatly improve our daily lives in areas such as portable electronics and optics, energy saving and green manufacturing.


This project will further advance the chemically vapor deposited carbide-bonded graphene coating process demonstrated during Phase I that involved using silicon wafers with micro/nano-patterning. With the help of our industrial partners we now intend to scale the technology to the commercial level. The process development is targeted to developing low-cost and mass-producible high precision glass molding, micro-optics, and NIR aspheric optics for cell phones and high performance laser collimators. These activities would also enhance our understanding of carbide-bonded graphene coating technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Carbide-Bonded Graphene Coating for Enhanced Glass Molding

1. Intellectual merit

Nanomaterial Innovation Ltd and partner LightPath Technologies carried out a Chemical Vapor Deposition (CVD) based Carbide Bonded Graphene (CBG) coating process on the surface of wafer level concave/convex, lens array silicon/germanium molds, and used the CBG coated molds in high precision/ infrared glass molding process. The research activities combined basic nanotechnology, novel CVD CBG coating technology, and low-cost and mass-producible high precision/infrared glass molding. These activities improved our understanding about the CBG technology and its potential applications in the glass/plastic molding industry.

 

2. Broader of impacts

Because of its unique combination of excellent mechanical, physical, optical transparency and biocompatibility properties together with tunable optoelectronic characteristics, this low-cost CVD-CBG technology and novel coating materials can be applied to a very broad range of applications, including advanced thermal management, next generation electronic components and biosensors.

 

3. We summarize the major findings as follow:

CBG properties

A CVD based CBG coating process was developed. The thickness of CBG could be controlled from nano level to micron level, depending on the coating conditions such as temperature, time and C/Si ratio. A scanning electron microscope imaging of both HOPG (Highly oriented pyrolytic graphite) and CBG shows similar well-ordered graphene layers. Scratching under an exactly same force reveals that stacked CBG layers hold much tighter than those in HOPG. Comparing to diamond-like carbon, CVD based CBG coating has less surface roughness, lower friction coefficient, good Young modulus and Hertzian hardness, higher thermal conductivity and tunable electric resistance.

 

Measurements of adhesion with glass

Silicon or germanium cannot work directly as mold material due to its severe adhesion to glass at elevated temperatures. This adhesion is usually caused by anodic bonding or other chemical reactions. It is critical to eliminate the adhesion problem such that silicon/germanium with fine features can be used as molds for precision/infrared glass molding. CBG coating is an ideal solution to solve this problem because it can prevent the direct bonding between glass and molds (Fig.1, 2).

 

Germanium CBG coating for the molds of concave/convex and lens array

Fig. 2 shows the convex and concave germanium molds. The uniformity of the coating was greatly improved for both concave and convex shapes. Roughness and form measurements on the two germanium mold surfaces indicate that:

(1) Application of the CBG coating did not significantly alter the radius of the molds. Change in radius was no more than one micron. This is very important, since maintaining the optical accuracy of the molds is critical. Optical performance of a molded lens would change with a significant change in base radius.

(2) The application of the CBG coating did not result in significant non-uniformity when two mold radius measurements were made at 90 degrees. The presence of non-uniformity in the coating can result in optical aberrations such as astigmatism.

(3) Roughness as measured was within acceptable limits for infrared lenses.

A wafer level CBG coated germanium lens array mold and a molded infrared lens array are shown in Fig. 3. The quality of both lens elements and mold cavities were measured and we found that lens roughness was significantly better than the roughness of the mold.

 

CBG coated silicon mold for infrared lens molding

Molding infrared glasses using a CBG coated mold was characterized for mold life. Almost 1000 infrared lenses have been pressed with no apparent decline in the surface quality and the molded lenses still pass the cosmetic inspection.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Carbide-Bonded Graphene Coating for Enhanced Glass Molding 1. Intellectual merit Nanomaterial Innovation Ltd and partner LightPath Technologies carried out a Chemical Vapor Deposition (CVD) based Carbide Bonded Graphene (CBG) coating process on the surface of wafer level concave/convex, lens array silicon/germanium molds, and used the CBG coated molds in high precision/ infrared glass molding process. The research activities combined basic nanotechnology, novel CVD CBG coating technology, and low-cost and mass-producible high precision/infrared glass molding. These activities improved our understanding about the CBG technology and its potential applications in the glass/plastic molding industry. 2. Broader of impacts Because of its unique combination of excellent mechanical, physical, optical transparency and biocompatibility properties together with tunable optoelectronic characteristics, this low-cost CVD-CBG technology and novel coating materials can be applied to a very broad range of applications, including advanced thermal management, next generation electronic components and biosensors. 3. We summarize the major findings as follow: CBG properties A CVD based CBG coating process was developed. The thickness of CBG could be controlled from nano level to micron level, depending on the coating conditions such as temperature, time and C/Si ratio. A scanning electron microscope imaging of both HOPG (Highly oriented pyrolytic graphite) and CBG shows similar well-ordered graphene layers. Comparing to diamond-like carbon, CVD based CBG coating has less surface roughness, lower friction coefficient, good Young modulus and Hertzian hardness, higher thermal conductivity and tunable electric resistance. Measurements of adhesion with glass Silicon or germanium cannot work directly as mold material due to its severe adhesion to glass at elevated temperatures. This adhesion is usually caused by anodic bonding or other chemical reactions. It is critical to eliminate the adhesion problem such that silicon/germanium with fine features can be used as molds for precision/infrared glass molding. CBG coating is an ideal solution to solve this problem because it can prevent the direct bonding between glass and molds (Fig.1, 2). Germanium CBG coating for the molds of concave/convex and lens array Fig. 2 shows the convex and concave germanium molds. The uniformity of the coating was greatly improved for both concave and convex shapes. Roughness and form measurements on the two germanium mold surfaces indicate that: (1) Application of the CBG coating did not significantly alter the radius of the molds. Change in radius was no more than one micron. This is very important, since maintaining the optical accuracy of the molds is critical. Optical performance of a molded lens would change with a significant change in base radius. (2) The application of the CBG coating did not result in significant non-uniformity when two mold radius measurements were made at 90 degrees. The presence of non-uniformity in the coating can result in optical aberrations such as astigmatism. (3) Roughness as measured was within acceptable limits for infrared lenses. A wafer level CBG coated germanium lens array mold and a molded infrared lens array are shown in Fig. 3. The quality of both lens elements and mold cavities were measured and we found that lens roughness was significantly better than the roughness of the mold. CBG coated silicon mold for infrared lens molding Molding infrared glasses using a CBG coated mold was characterized for mold life. Almost 1000 infrared lenses have been pressed with no apparent decline in the surface quality and the molded lenses still pass the cosmetic inspection.
